column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) or who qualify for special exemptions. Travellers must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival. They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:
• Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
• Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
• Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- travellers from some countries face stricter measures.
Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Lithuania's national classification of risk areas:
• Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
• Passengers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
• Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
• Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.

column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU:

All travellers entering this country must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

Travellers must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:

  • Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
  • Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
  • Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).

Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Lithuania's national classification of risk areas:

  • Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
  • Passengers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
  • Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
  • Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.

Health cover for temporary stays



*Transit:

Travellers in transit must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

Transit is allowed for citizens of non-EU/Schengen area countries: 

  • On their return to their country of residence;
  • In whose respect a reasoned request has been made by a foreign country;
  • Via the territory of the Russian Federation to Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation and backward (via Kena railway border checkpoint and Kybartai railway border checkpoint).

 



*From Third Countries:

Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) or who qualify for special exemptions.

Travellers must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:

  • Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
  • Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
  • Negative test (within 72 hours) or antigen test (within 48 hours).

Entry requirements depend on the colour attributed to the country of departure, according to Lithuania's national classification of risk areas:

  • Passengers arriving from red, grey and black countries/areas must self-isolate for 10 days and follow mandatory isolation regulations.
  • Passengers from red or grey countries/areas, if they are vaccinated or recovered, need not comply with testing and self-isolation requirements.
  • Passengers arriving from orange and green countries do not have to self-isolate.
  • Passengers arriving from black countries/areas, even if they are vaccinated or recovered, must self-isolate until they produce a negative test result.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



Internal Restrictions:
*Facemasks: You must wear a medical facemask in all indoor public spaces in Lithuania, including shops, restaurants, businesses, workplaces, museums, theatres, public transport, taxis and educational environments.
Masks should be three layers of non-woven material and bear the CE marking on their packaging.
This does not apply to children under the age of six, or people with a medical exemption. If you cannot wear facemasks on medical grounds, you are advised to wear face shields if possible. Exemptions also apply to those doing physical exercise, providing a service that cannot be done with a facemask, or consuming food or drink.
*Public places and services: A number of restrictions apply to those not vaccinated against COVID-19.
Foreign nationals resident in Lithuania may be able to apply for the Lithuanian Freedom Pass, to prove their vaccination status. More information about registering for the pass is available on the Lithuanian Ministry of the Economy and Innovation website. The pass is designed to be used for public services in Lithuania, it is not considered valid proof of vaccination status for the purpose of international travel.
If you are aged 16 or over and do not have a Lithuanian Freedom Pass, you will need to have proof of one of the following in order to access the majority of non-essential services:
• Confirmation that you completed a full course of a COVID-19 vaccine approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) within the last seven months; or
• Confirmation that you have had an EMA approved COVID-19 vaccine booster within the last seven months; or
• A negative COVID-19 PCR test result, taken within the last 72 hours. PCR tests for individuals aged 16 and over, for the purpose of a Freedom Pass, will be charged.
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19 in the last seven months
Children from the age of 12 years and two months, but under 16 must have proof of one of the following in order to access non-essential services:
• Confirmation that they had their first dose of EMA approved vaccine no earlier than two weeks and no later than 12 weeks before. Or, confirmation of a second dose of EMA approved COVID-19 vaccine at least one week before. COVID-19 vaccines are available to all children aged five years and older in Lithuania.
• A negative COVID-19 PCR test result, taken within the last seven days. Tests for children under 16 are available free of charge.
• Proof of recovery from COVID-19, confirmed by a negative PCR test, in the last seven months
Lithuania will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record, if it meets the requirements set out above. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
More information on COVID-19 related restrictions to public places and services in Lithuania is available on the KoronaStop website . *If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
